simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: Hiring managers judge HR Managers on shortlist quality when speed and stakes are high.
primary_role_competencies_evaluated: Signal vs noise judgment under pressure

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Hiring manager demands a 5-candidate shortlist by EOD after recruiter dropout.
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Hiring manager questions speed vs quality trade-off

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Conflicting feedback appears on shortlisted candidates.

workplace_context.business_state: Hiring audit and interview pipeline review

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Interview outcomes reflect poorly on shortlist quality.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Hiring review email & shortlist rationale doc

step_level_design.instruction_question: Filter resumes to identify immediate role-fit candidates.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: At senior levels, speed without relevance damages credibility. This task evaluates how you quickly narrow down candidates using must-have criteria that directly affect time-to-hire and interview success. Focus on what makes someone interview-ready today, not potentially trainable later. The business impact is reducing wasted interview bandwidth and protecting hiring manager trust.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You scan an ATS dashboard and apply filters to surface resumes that meet core role requirements.
options_inputs: Select candidates meeting all JD must-haves
Select candidates with strong brand-name companies
Select candidates with career growth signals
step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Your choice impacts interviewer confidence and hiring velocity.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Reduce the shortlist to five under time pressure.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are often forced to choose under incomplete information. This step tests whether you can make defensible trade-offs that balance speed and quality. Success here means the shortlist can survive scrutiny later, even if not perfect. Business value lies in momentum without reckless risk.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You reorder candidates and lock five profiles for review.
options_inputs: Balance skill match with tenure stability
step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Your ordering affects perceived judgment under pressure.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Flag potential risks before sending the shortlist.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: Strong HR Managers do not hide uncertainty—they surface it early. This step checks if you can anticipate concerns and protect downstream trust. The business impact is avoiding surprise failures during interviews or post-hire.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You annotate shortlisted profiles with risk notes.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Send the shortlist with a concise rationale.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: Executives judge HR Managers on clarity, not volume. This evaluates whether you can justify decisions in business language. The outcome affects how much autonomy you are given in future hiring.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You draft a short rationale note attached to the shortlist.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Respond to feedback questioning shortlist quality.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: When challenged, HR Managers are evaluated on ownership, not blame-shifting. This step tests your ability to protect credibility while remaining open to correction. Business value comes from maintaining trust during friction.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You reply to a hiring manager’s critical email.
options_inputs: Acknowledge gaps and propose next steps
step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Your response affects future decision autonomy.

end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.
